A number of business associations have developed strategies for sustainable development and climate
change, including cooperate social responsibility (CSR). International initiatives have inclu
promotion of CSR initiatives by international investors in low
income countries to support a broad
range of development priorities, including social working conditions, eliminating child labour and
evaluated the role of mining industries in
d concluded that, although the industry has
played a positive role in avoiding migration and pressure on forest resources, there is a lack of
coordination between government and industry initiatives.
It can be concluded that most of the
mitigation options in industry considered in this section could have
synergies with the SDGs, but also that some of the renewable
energy options could indicate some trade
offs in relation to land use, with implications for food
and storage could play an enabling role
in the provision of reliable, sustainable and modern energy and
support decarbonisation, but it can also be costly
provision of water for CCS can include both synergies and trade
(Giannaris et al. 2020; IEAGHG 2020; Mikunda et al.
With 80% of the global population expected to be urban by 2050, cities will shape devel
. The challenge for many policymakers is to construct
development paths that make cities clean, prosperous and liveable while mitigating climate change and
building resilience to heatwaves, flooding and other climate
risks. The IPCC 1.5 report sees achieving
these objectives as feasible: cities could potentially realize significant climate and sustainable
development benefits from shifting development paths
offs between meeting the SDGs and climate
providing a general overview of miti
gation options in cities and of enabling factors, including city
networks and plans for jointly addressing the SDGs and climate
Chapter 8 concludes that urban areas potentially offer several joint benefits between mitigation and the
since AR5, evidence of the co
benefits of urban mitigation continues to grow. In
benefits approach that frames climate objectives alongside other
e increasingly being seen as an important con
Puppum De Oliveria 2018; Seto et al. 2016)
benefits of urban mitigation measures on human health has increased significantly
since the IPCC AR5, especially through the use of health
impact assessments in cities like Geneva,
supply structures based on measures for urban planning,
heating and transport have reduced CO
, NOx and PM10 emissions and increased the opportunities for
physical activity for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases
There is increasing evidence that climate
mitigation measures can lower health risks that are related to
ially in vulnerable groups, such as the elderly
Moreover, the use of urban forestry and green infrastructure as both a climate mitigation and
adaptation measure can reduce heat stress
(Kim and Coseo 2019; Privitera and La Rosa 2017)
removing air pollutants to improve air quality
(Scholz et al. 2018; De la Sota et al. 2019)
being, including contributions to local development and possible red
. Other studies evidence the potential to reduce premature mortality by up to 7,000 in 53
93,000 net new jobs and lower global climate costs, as well as
nal energy costs based on road
